Thank you @Jet! Question here - it looks like there are a ton of subspaces in the admin's space that are public, meaning that anyone could navigate here and access the data. Is this on purpose?
it's one of our 23.04 sandbox, shared same username and password
Also @Xindi Xu do you have capacity for this one? I can take a look tomorrow otherwise
@Jet I mean literally anyone, not just people with the 1pass credentials. It's a special type of subspace
Try logging out and going here: https://release-23-04-0.aws.sandbox.instabase.com/admin/jet-test/fs/Instabase%20Drive/
When i log off, it seems I still have access to all the drives, but I'm unsure if this is expected.
I won't be able to look at this :cry: .
yup, i still have access to the URL even when i logoff
@Xindi Xu I'll put up the fix tomorrow!
that's weird ,  i still have the url access regardless

It is expected because they're public subspaces. We should a) change the settings of the non system test ones, b) delete the system test ones, c) fix the system tests to create private instead of public subspaces
even in incognito mode ?
Yep, anyone at all with the url. It was a feature used mostly by universities
I just disabled public subspaces for this sandbox, but we should still make sure there are no other sandboxes have these public subspaces and fix the system tests creating them
The setting is here
got it, several IB sandbox are public, didn't know that setting until now
:joy: even our dogfood and Prod IB env
should i turn it off on dogfood and platform.IB?
We might actually use some public subspaces on dogfood, I’m assuming we’re not purposefully using them on any sandboxes though
I can make a PSA tomorrow that people should make sure that either that setting is on or that people should be making sure the default privacy setting for subspaces they’re creating isn’t changed
I'm wondering if, for SaaS clients or on-prem, the setting is on by default. Otherwise, it's a big security issue.:sweat_smile:
That’s a very good question. Our clients probably do not want to risk accidentally setting a subspace to public
:joy:  sorry i was meant by default is it on or off

Well it’s technically okay if the setting is off and public subspaces are allowed - it would just mean that users have to be careful not to set any of their subspaces to public. I agree that in most cases for saas customers they’d want to disable public subspaces completely though
We've disabled public repos in SaaS envs (the env var `ENABLE_PUBLIC_REPOS` is off by default)
